An ugly scenario - one in which a hard lockdown was forced by factors beyond our control - is much less likely but could be caused by a new vaccine-evading variant of Covid.

A recent Sage paper described this as a  reasonable possibility , meaning it was between 40-50 percent  probable.

Alastair McLellan, editor of the Health Service Journal, is not optimistic. Asked for his good, bad or ugly prediction:

 Its either going to be bad or very ugly. The obvious thing to say is that its bad right now.  The system is already very overstretched.

What does the bad outcome look like?

Experts say a bad outcome will essentially be what the UK has seen twice before.

Cases rise again, followed by growth in hospitalisations and deaths. Masks, vaccine passports and stronger communications are introduced but to no avail.

The best case scenario ğŸ‘‡

Things continue largely as they are, with everything open and people - slowly but surely - returning to life as normal.

Andrew Lilico, a proponent of this view, believes that  in England at least, the coronavirus epidemic is now de facto at an end .

The only real question we Britons are asking at the moment is this: will there be another lockdown this winter?

We spoke to many of the countryâ€™s leading experts. Here are their thoughts on the months ahead.

As far back as 1913, a doctor was investigating the potential menstrual impact of typhoid vaccines.

Having ruled out a close associate of Otto Frank or neighbours, the Pankoke team focused on the Jewish Council, a body set up by the Nazis in Amsterdam to help implement its policies

For decades the finger was pointed at Wilhelm van Maaren, a warehouseman. 

But he was ruled out by the Pankoke investigation, which pointed out he would have lost his job if Mr Frankâ€™s business collapsed
Led by retired FBI detective, Vince Pankoke, the team used artificial intelligence to comb through voluminous records to reach its conclusion

The results of a painstaking investigation, using 21st-century detection techniques, were revealed by CBS in its flagship documentary series, 60 Minutes, naming Arnold van den Bergh, who died in 1950 as the individual most likely to have been responsible for the betrayal

Read more about the study here ğŸ‘‡
Researchers believe the study opens the door to understanding the ageing process, and the inevitability and timing of death
The average human lifespan in the study was 83.6 years, but the mutation rate was far lower at around 47

ğŸ€It explains how a five-inch long naked mole rat can live for 25 years, about the same as a far larger giraffe, which typically lives for 24. 

When scientists checked their mutation rates, they were  similar.

Naked mole rats suffer 93 mutations a year and giraffes 99

But a new study from the Wellcome Sanger Institute in Cambridge suggests the speed of genetic damage could be the key to survival, with long-living animals successfully slowing down their rate of DNA mutations regardless of their size
â¡ï¸Previously experts have suggested that size is the key to longevity, with smaller animals burning up energy more quickly, requiring a faster cell turnover, which causes a speedier decline
ğŸ§¬Humans and animals die after amassing a similar number of genetic mutations, researchers have found, suggesting the speed of DNA errors is critical in determining the lifespan of a species

From temporary twinges to monumental migraines, here is everything you need to know about easing your pain â¤µï¸
ğŸ‘ï¸ Eye strain headaches occur because when you focus on a screen at close range, the muscles in and around your eyes need to work harder, and become sore and tired over time

ğŸŸ  Eye strain headaches

Eye strain can trigger both a tension headache and a migraine, but it can also be a form of headache in its own right. 

Eye strain headaches typically appear when you focus on something for a long period of time

ğŸŸ  Medication overuse headaches

Rebound headaches are the bane of many regular headache sufferersâ€™ lives, as they occur when someone frequently uses painkillers such as paracetamol, ibuprofen, triptans or opiates for at least three months

Far more common in men, this type of headache tends to occur in a rhythmical fashion at the same time each day. 

â¡ï¸ They require specialist treatments to relieve the pain, such as oxygen therapy, sumatriptan injections or nasal spray

ğŸŸ  Cluster headaches

A rare type of severe headache, characterised by excruciating pain on one side of the head, often around the eyes. 

 A cluster headache is considered to be one of the most painful conditions known to humans,  says Todd Schwedt, a professor of neurology

ğŸŸ  Covid headaches

The data from the Covid Symptoms Study states that headaches are now one of the earliest signs of Covid-19

Covid headaches tend to be a pulsing, pressing or stabbing pain, occurring across both sides of the head rather than just one area

â¡ï¸ While they can be treated with common painkillers they can be an indication of dehydration, lack of sleep, emotional stress, dental problems such as jaw clenching or teeth grinding, or too much caffeine

ğŸŸ  Tension headaches

These are by far the most common type.

Unlike migraine, they cause a steady, mild to moderate ache rather than a throbbing one and do not tend to come with nausea or sensitivity to light and sound
â¡ï¸Common migraine triggers include stress, skipping meals and inadequate sleep, which is why consistency in your daily routine can help reduce the likelihood of attacks

ğŸŸ  Migraines

This is characterised as a severe throbbing headache on one side of the head, which can be accompanied by blurred vision, nausea and acute sensitivity to light and sound

ğŸ§ Overall there are more than 100 different clinical categories of headaches, ranging from temporary twinges to severe and even life-threatening ones. 

Here is a guide to some of them and their causes, as well as ways of preventing and treating them â¤µï¸

ğŸ¤• If you woke up with a headache this morning, you are far from alone. 

A new study has found that around one in six people worldwide will experience some form of pounding head pain today 

So, whats the cause? â¤µï¸

In the psyche of the country, there was this respect for the people who had held the line. 

Gen Parker says the Ukrainians desire to reform both  externally and internally  demonstrates why  Ukraine is a country that believes in itself enough to resist in the way that it has

The first time he went into a meeting with senior Ukrainian military officials, a group of  thirty-somethings in civilian clothes  gently contradicted some of the generalsâ€™ assumptions.

Gen Parker was impressed to see the civilians being listened to by the military leaders

The vast majority were younger, well-meaning, committed people who just picked up a rifle and went. 

Over the next two years, there was an internal transformation of the Ukrainian armed forces, guided in part by Gen Parker

The insurrection in the Donbas was only contained by Kyiv after  frantic scrambling  pulled forces together.

 It was extraordinary how volunteers just picked themselves up and managed to hold the line,  Gen Parker told the Telegraph

In 2016 Stepan Poltorak, the Ukrainian defence minister, had requested a group of advisers from multiple countries to help him reform his countrys Ministry of Defence.

Britain sent General Sir Nick Parker, a man known to back himself, even if he  got told off afterwards

Many observers have asked how, just eight years later, Ukraine has been able to mount such fierce resistance to the latest act of Russian aggression.

It is a story of deep reflection and transition guided by advice from afar

In 2014, Ukraine was a country in turmoil.

Despite the Maidan Revolution, there were Russian troops in Crimea and Moscow-backed separatists in the eastern Donbas region.

The country seemed weak, vulnerable and ripe for another strike from Moscow

â¡ï¸Dr Davies also revealed that the Neanderthal gene first infiltrated humans 60,000 years ago after one interspecies tryst between a human and a neanderthal.

ğŸ—£ This tiny section of DNA doubles your risk of dying from Covid,  said Prof Davies.
